metadata.name: Florescence #247
metadata.description:
Digitally crafted flowers in pots for virtual window sills.

In the spirit of the piranha plant from the Mario Bros videogame. We wanted to create a project that acknowledges the playful depiction of nature in early videogames by creating a retro futuristic collectible that explores aesthetics over gameplay, whilst preserving the playful energy of these early digital worlds. There are many game elements that have emerged over the years that have become iconic in their own right. Their memorable designs have come to represent the exciting feeling of when we first discovered these worlds, but over time an appreciation for their simple design execution, harmony and balance has emerged. Art can exist in many forms and places including a digital pot plant.

Rarity:

There are a total of 23 hand-drawn and animated sprites divided into 4 groups Firelillies, Flytraps, Quasars and Stargazers and there are 15 possible combinations made from these 4 groups. 18% of the collection is a combination of these 4 groups which we can call random and the remaining 72% is divided between the remaining 14 combinations.


There are 3 possible grid systems 1x1, 3x3 and 4x4 

3% 1x1

40% 3x3

57% 4x4



There are 14 possible placement points for all grids and 76 stem/sprite arragement in total



For the pots and stems there are 11 colors to choose and  no rarities for color combinations.



The flower distribution can be either symmetric or random. 35% symmetric and 65% random



Export options:

Pressing 's' on desktop or holding for 2 seconds will download gif to whatever the current device resolution is. To export at a different resolution open the token in new window by clicking 'open' link under the token image and add "&exportsize=1080" or "&exportsize=2160" to end of the url and hit enter then either hold for 2 seconds or press 's' to create gif and download.

metadata.name: Fireworks #182
metadata.description:
Fireworks by Hevey (@HeveyArt).

This artwork was created using p5js.

metadata.name: Charcoal Brutalism #155
metadata.description:
Based on a similar technique as "Charcoal Landscapes", using lines limited to 8 possible directions, this work is about the repetition of patterns at different scales and the use of negative spaces.
The texture created from the noise combined with the structures that emerges from this algorithm create a look similar to the brutalist architecture of the last century.

There are 10 scale variations but with almost infinite possible outcomes.
Inverted colours have a small chance of dropping.

Original artwork by William Watkins · Lyon, 2022

metadata.name: Balance #11
metadata.description: Experimenting with a different approach to dynamic math fields.  Each component influences the final piece, imbalance causes unexpected results - some complementary, some not. There is harmony in balance.

metadata.name: Mining Structures #112
metadata.description: Press 's' to save a high resolution image.

metadata.name: Dithered Nostalgia #193
metadata.description:
Have you ever struck by a sudden surge of nostalgia?
Making you stop everything you did at that moment,
Trying hard to remember the memory behind it, and failed to do so?

Each of these lands hold a nostalgia unlocked,
Like how good nostalgia are, it’s dithered and full of holes.
Holes that can be filled with your own memories and interpretations.

• • •

The second collaboration of MEK.txt and IceRain in FXHash. This time using MEK.txt’s landscape pixelart series and its distinctive dithering textures, brilliantly translated into code by IceRain to pixel-perfect iterations.

Dithered Nostalgia is a step up from MEK.txt & IceRain’s first project (Bento Boxes), trying to make more sophisticated, more detailed and challenging things based on something they passionate about; landscape.

Controls:
[1] Set the resolution to Medium Resolution
[2] Set the resolution to High Resolution

metadata.name: Damo's Cave #34
metadata.description:
As my exciting journey through fxhash this year is coming to an end, learning about generative art creating and collecting is like getting out of Plato’s Cave, figuratively. I explore visually to the best of my coding ability, on the topics I have always thought about inside my cave, eg nothingness, void and non-void, tea ceremonies, musical composition, ambiguous landscape, I-ching, teardrops and memories of my grandparents, collaboration in GAN and glitch calligraphy, staring at temple stone garden, last but not least collaborating on a children’s book with absurd narratives.  

Looking back on the journey this year, I would like to crawl back inside to my cave now, not unlike Damo and his cave. Wall gazing or meditating or remembering each of my creative impulses for each drop. What I truly see, not necessarily in sight, is me, literally my code in my Damo’s Cave. 

Private release at 100tz. Public release starting at 200tz. Prices are subject to change at any price above 200tz.

Please be patient, rendering is hard on the laptop, avg rendering time is 116.32 seconds. 

Press ‘2’ to save png. 

Licensed under CC BY-NC-SA 4.0

Notes on Damo
Damo (達摩), aka Bodhidharma, aka Daruma, a semi-legendary Buddhist monk, credited as the transmitter of Zen Buddhism to China, and regarded as its first Chinese patriarch. 

The legend of 9 years of wall-gazing goes something like, after failing to make a favorable impression in China, Damo is said to have travelled to the Shaolin Monastery. After either being refused entry or being ejected after a short time, he lived in a nearby cave, where he "faced a wall for nine years, not speaking for the entire time". An inward introspection of the self. 

The biographical tradition is littered with apocryphal tales about Damo's life and circumstances. In one version of the story, he is said to have fallen asleep seven years into his nine years of wall-gazing. Becoming angry with himself, he cut off his eyelids to prevent it from happening again. According to the legend, as his eyelids hit the floor the first tea plants sprang up, and thereafter tea would provide a stimulant to help keep students of Zen awake during zazen.

In contrast to Plato’s Cave, Plato’s Cave is about those who are freed from the cave come to understand that the shadows on the wall are actually not the direct source of the images seen. A philosopher  aims to understand and perceive the higher levels of reality. However, the other inmates of the cave do not even desire to leave their prison, for they know no better life. An artist aims the same but also has many desires to express understanding and perceptions. An outward extraversion of the senses.

metadata.name: A Bugged Forest #43
metadata.description:
A forest has stories to tell.
About times that were, about times that will be.
-
This project was minted in much unusual conditions. 
We gathered here, by 38 degrees heat. We belong to a crowd who loves stories, of civilisations at stake and deities, of afterlife and worship. We drank and hugged and chanted pagan hymns. We minted the Bugged Forest from our place on earth that we call Hell just for the fun of it. We are passionate, and loving, and angry and desperate. We, people of the soil, under a bugged sun.
-
This project is the long-form version of an algorithm that contains a bug. “The Bugged Tree”’s code was salvaged and stored and served as the core motivation and engine for an entire forest. Its concept is about releasing the control. I am a  byproduct of evolution, an iteration of that specie who wanted utter control, and which at some point, lost control over its own creation. As a generative artist, I chose to welcome the event of chance into my creative process. The symbolism in chance made me feel humble and free. Unwilling to make any change to a story that the Tree needed to tell me, as a listener, rather than a writer of my own idealised fantasies.
-
The iterations aren’t under control. They may be odd and off. We have to accept it. They are also plottable, press [s] in live mode to get a SVG. Attempt the plot at your own risk, as there’s a possibility for it to come near to impossibilities or cause paper or motor damage, and most certainly, a bugged drawing.
-
From Earth or from Hell, with love, yours truthfully, NFTBiker and zancan

metadata.name: Cités nuageuses #78
metadata.description:
Un de mes frères s’est envolé hier. Ou avant-hier, je ne sais plus. Il a vendu du lest pour sortir une fille. Une bourrasque soudaine les a emportés, lui et ses deux tickets de cinéma.

Cela fait bien trois semaines que nous n’avons pas eu de livraison. Pas de courrier non plus, par la même occasion. J’en reçois rarement. Je n’ai jamais reçu qu’une lettre, en réalité. C’était une longue lettre épistolaire de mon ami Dino. Il est cowboy, dans une cité voisine. 

Mon frère connaissait cette fille depuis bien cinq ou six ans. Il étaient au collège ensemble. Il y avait encore des livraisons toutes les semaines, à cette époque. Parfois deux fois par semaine. On pouvait vendre des enclumes et acheter du petit lest. Poids pour poids, on y perdait. Mais avec ça on arrivait quand même à vivre.

C’était le temps où les rochers n’étaient pas attachés. Ils dérivaient rarement, le vent n’était pas si fort. Et ils étaient plus denses aussi. Aujourd’hui, un rocher qui n’est pas en laisse ne sera plus là demain.

À l’époque, j’étais moi-même cowboy. Je vivais avec Jacques, un bon copain. Il n’y avait rien de sexuel entre nous. On gardait les rochers. Un soir, on jouait à l’espagnolette, il m’a relancé de trois alors que j’étais atout trèfle. Vous imaginez la suite. Je ne l’ai plus jamais revu après ça.

Plus personne ne va au collège. Mon frère était d’une des dernières générations. Après ça les gens ne voyaient plus l’intérêt. Tout devient de plus en plus léger, et apprendre à lire ou écrire ne pèse rien. Plus on mine, plus on vends des enclumes, plus on peut acheter du lest. Mais comme le lest est plus cher que les enclumes, à force, la cité devient de moins en moins lourde.

Le vent est de plus en plus fort aussi. Je pense que c’est pour ça qu’il y a moins de livraisons. Il y a de moins en moins de cités qui arrivent à rester suspendues. Celle de Dino s’est envolée l’année dernière, Dino avec. Avec moins de cités à visiter par voyage, les livraisons sont moins rentables.

Avant d’être cowboy je construisais des ponts. C’est comme ça que j’ai appris à lier les rochers. Plus personne ne le fait aujourd’hui. Il faut commencer par ancrer le rocher domestique. Et après, il faut attendre. C’est la partie la plus difficile. Personne n’a appris à suffisamment attendre. Parce que plus le temps passe, plus on devient légers. Mais c’est le plus important. Il faut attendre le que rocher sauvage devienne suffisamment léger. Sinon, il emportera le rocher domestique avec lui et on aura tout perdu.

Je me demande pourquoi il a acheté ces deux tickets de cinéma. C’est toujours le même film qui passe. Je ne l’ai jamais vu. Ça parle de dialectique et de maçonnerie, il paraît. Le cinéma c’est un domaine que je trouve trop contraignant. Encore une idée de bureaucrate. Places assignées. Horaires fixes. Un processus administratif au profit de la structure sociale. Classique. Les bureaucrates commencent toujours par nous exploiter et ils finissent par nous aliéner. “Servir le peuple”, ils appellent ça. 

Cela fait des années que le pont est de moins en moins solide. De toutes les façons, on n’a rien pour le réparer. Nos rochers sont domestiqués depuis le temps, mais ils s’entrainent les uns les autres au lieu de se stabiliser. La suspension des cités, ça a l’air simple mais ça ne l’est pas vraiment. Quand elles ont été construites, avec les machines-outils des livreurs, elles étaient bien suspendues. Mais peu à peu, elles se sont dégradées. La seule richesse des cités, c’est leur gravité. Pourquoi réparer ce qui est destiné à s’envoler ?

Je comprends pourquoi mon frère a vendu du lest. Après tout, le lest est là pour être vendu tant qu’il vaut encore quelque chose. Jeudi dernier, le pont est tombé. Notre deuxième rocher majeur est toujours relié par la chaine des rochers mineurs, mais elle ne va pas tenir longtemps. La cité va s’envoler bientôt. Peut-être demain ou après-demain. Je vous laisse, je dois aller miner.

metadata.name: monogrid 1.1 CE #99
metadata.description:
Each monogrid artwork gets initialized with a start up algorithm that builds up a set of rectangles and fills them with pixels. There are two different styles, 'Pixel' and 'Line', to create the initial image.

There is a set of 16 animations at work. 4 noise based animations, 4 shifting animations, 4 modulo based animation and 4 reset animations, all run in parallel. Each animation selects a rectangle from the initial setup and edits the pixels in this area. The selection process runs independently and animations can overlap which results in a new style of animation.

monogrid 1.1 is based on the original series at https://monogrid.xyz, but there are no black/white versions included. The color palette is a mixture of one of 12 colors plus black or white.
The fragment shader has been updated in the way the 16 different animations get summed up. This version would appear more chaotic and organic.

monogrid 1.1 - Collectors Edition
Kim Asendorf, 2022

metadata.name: CENTURY-XXX-METABILL #96
metadata.description: Press 'spacebar' to change background color.

metadata.name: Ordinary Places #112
metadata.description:
“Ordinary Places” is a fully-coded meditation on the poetic beauty of everyday landscapes. 

The architectural characters in these landscapes include water towers (inspired by Bernd & Hilla Becher’s “Water Tower” photography series), gas stations (inspired by Ed Ruscha’s “26 Gasoline Stations” photography book), and barns (inspired by childhood memories on my grandfather’s farm). 

Yet, while these scenes may seem ordinary upon first glance, something darker lurks beneath the surface. The hidden secrets of these Ordinary Places can only be revealed through the minting process. In this sense, the outputs are not merely a collection individual scenes, but instead, a coherent world animated by shared themes and narratives.     

Pressing the down arrow saves the coded output as a .png image.

metadata.name: ribbon #20
metadata.description:
a grayscale composition with a cloth-like shape as a subject

made in p5.js

metadata.name: Enchanted #11
metadata.description:
Illustrations from The Collection of Most Beautiful Fairy Tales I had and puzzles with a painting by Ivan Rabuzin owned by one of my friends are deeply embedded in my childhood memory as images I was enchanted by and wished I knew how to make. Recently, searching for both items in antique stores, it turned out the illustrations, although still beautiful, aren't the same as I remember them. Rabuzin's oeuvre is rich and is a direct inspiration for this project, but I failed to find any evidence those puzzles ever existed and possibly are the product of my imagination. 

The same case is with fairy tales and their true and "untrue" nature. A hero embarks on a journey where various events unfold in seemingly random or loosely connected ways. The occurrences sometimes lead to improbable plot twists, but these enigmatic transformations ultimately bring the story full circle, evoking a sense of familiarity combined with an air of mystery.

On this Enchanted journey, you might end up in one of five possible scenes: Fairy Lake, Magic Wetlands, Giant's Woods, Over 7 Seas and 7 Mountains, or Enchanted Forest. Look out for the FOMO keyboard key to visit more locations.

Use [s] key in live view to save output as PNG. 

----
Enchanted was part of the Blind Gallery x Feral File Vistas Edition.
Learn more at https://www.blindgallery.xyz/

metadata.name: reborn #154
metadata.description:
This is an album of cities too ideal to ever materialise.

It consists of 256 algorithmically generated plans that resemble drawings of Vincenzo Scamozzi, Pietro Cataneo, Filarete and other theorists of the Italian Renaissance. The cities differ in size, the grid of the streets, the landscape around them and the people that inhabit their utopian walls. They carry names that are Italian exonyms of real European cities, drawing a vision of a different world that enacts a mixture of military perfection with social superiority. Flawless, harmonious, unconquerable and utterly impossible.

History brought us many theories about ideal cities, but very few examples exist today. Italian Palmanova or Polish Zamość are the few to remind us how hard it is to shape reality according to ideals. When confronted with the material world, its idealism becomes the city's grates foe.

To zoom, press a mouse button over the image or touch the screen. To pan, keep the mouse pressed and move it around.

metadata.name: Hyper Drive: B-Side #18
metadata.description:
Hyper Drive is based on the mathematics of recursion. Scale symmetry is used to create patterns that repeat at ever-smaller intervals, creating the illusion of infinite depth and complexity.

The rule for the recursive loop is incredibly simple. A box is drawn, then a snapshot of the full canvas is resized to cover the boundary. As this process is repeated, small variations in position create endless fractals.

This project is an experimental cross-chain collection, with a fully-generative A-side published via Art Blocks on Ethereum and an AI-based image composition B-side published via fxhash on Tezos. The artwork symbolizes the great divides we must cross, the connections we make along the way, and the disconnections we feel. We move through the world as the world moves through us.

metadata.name: Ethereal Microcosm #243
metadata.description:
An exploration of algorithmic organisms in a contained environment.

This piece is about the simulation of microscopic patterns using a high number of even tinier agents all following the same rules. Different species evolve and interact together, resulting in stabilizing patterns out of their parametric configurations. A form of artificial life.

This work is based on the paper "Characteristics of pattern formation and evolution in approximations of physarum transport networks", written by Jeff Jones and popularized in the artistic field by Sage Jenson. Some features were added to increase the visual and behavioral complexity of the system. Agents are divided into different species, with their own set of rules and interacting with their own substrate. Substrates also interact with each other and agents will mutate in contact of some of them.

NFT License
Runs properly on Chrome 97.0.4692.99
GPU intensive

Press P to pause (double tab touch devices)
Press

metadata.name: Glomularus Redux #2
metadata.description:
'Glomularus Redux' is part of the fxhash live minting experience at Proof of People, ZeroSpace NYC, 2023.

The piece is the next chapter of my genesis fxhash project. The Glomularus series explores an artificial life form, advancing my Protobytes work from 2004. Using @ZeroSpaceNYC for reference and inspiration, 30 new industrial HDRI environments are included, as well as improved texturing and real-time shadows. Built with three.js and my own PByte.js library.

Interaction:

Mouse/Trackpad:
drag -> camera rotation
drag + CMD/CTR -> camera pan
scroll wheel/pinch -> camera zoom

Key Input:
1-9: add acceleration
-, +: reduce | increase V-eco sphere radius
p: screen capture

Tip:
To decrease creature acceleration, reduce V-eco sphere radius

Note:
Please post your favorite 'Glomularus Redux' screen captures
TW: @iragreenberg
IG: @greenberg.ira

Thank you Robin, Ian, Sophie, Eric and Hilary.
